ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Linux - F90 really required? which fortran compiler?  Scilab/Octave  connection ?

Steve,

You can very easily use Cantera in Fortran 77 applications.  In fact,  
it's funny you bring it up now, because I'm finishing up a short note  
on just that topic, and will release a new version this week that will  
contain a demo of using Cantera with Fortran 77.  In fact, if all you  
need is gas-phase thermo + chemical production rates, the demo contains  
a ready-to-use library of the Fortran-callable functions you need.

In the new version of Cantera, the Matlab toolbox contains only one MEX  
file that must be compiled. Hopefully this will simplify porting it to  
Scilab or Octave. I can't personally commit to working on that, due to  
time constraints, but welcome anyone else who is interested in  
developing interfaces for Scilab, Octave, or anything else.

The new version should be out very soon - maybe today, but more likely  
tomorrow.

Dave





On Tuesday, April 15, 2003, at 08:56 PM, steve@...  
wrote:

>
> My main work is done on a linux machine.
>
> I am considering switching from Chemkin II to cantera but don't
> have a Fortran-90 compiler.
>
> The manual is not really explicit about what functionality will
> be unavailable without  F90 compiler.
> I would be happy to program completely in C++/python  if
> that's a reasonable option.
>
> If F90 is really required, there seem to be many choices.
> Intel has a fullfeatured eval download, and there are others --
> any advice?
>
> Finally, while I'm here --
> given that Cantera is open source, how about
> an interface to Scilab, or Octave (both matlab replacements).
> I have a crude interface between Chemkin II and scilab
> and will  at least scope out a cantera<->scilab connection.
>
> 		Thanks
> 			Steve
